If it's "very high human development", there are places like Argentina and Belarus close or over that limit, but few people would consider these countries developed - usually because of high inequality, lack of stability, lack of economic diversity, and the like.The very concept of a developed nation today is very "polluted" by our standing examples (USA, EU, ANZAC, Japan-Singapore-South Korea), in the sense that we assume that a developed country will be like one of those and have common features like democracy - which is a political system and unrelated to high levels of economic development, as places like the UAE constantly lay bare to our viewing pleasure.So just a disclaimer to mention how difficult it can be to call a place either developed or developing. We usually have good references at the extremes (ie. Scandinavia and Central Africa) but the middle ground is quite convoluted.I think living standards across the world will continue to rise. It should not be that long before the less developed nations attain a dignified level of development similar to what current developed nations had in the post-WWII era, in that they'll have access to similar comforts, technology and amenities.As for who could presumably advance the most, I would say Argentina+Brazil+Colombia, Russia (here's another issue, is a former superpower developed or developing?), Turkey and Malaysia. All of these countries have political stability, a recent history of steady growth (notwithstanding Brazil's and Russia's recent woes, the big picture is optimistic) and still-untapped shares of internal markets to fuel growth, achievable also through increases on households' disposable incomes.
